awd_titl_txt: RUI: Quantifying the effects of wildfire burning on 10Be concentrations in river sand - A study of the 2018 Woolsey Fire, Santa Monica Mountains, CA
awd_abstract_narration:
The rates at which landscapes evolve over hundreds to thousands of years – geological erosion rates – provide important information about landscape stability, rates of sediment erosion or movement, seismic motion on faults, and the magnitude of human-caused erosion above background geological erosion. Exactly how geological erosion rates are affected by short-lived but large-magnitude erosive events such as floods, hurricanes, earthquakes, landslides, and wildfires remain poorly understood. This project focuses on the Woolsey Fire, which burned through ~100,000 acres of the Santa Monica Mountains, southern California, in November 2018. The Woolsey fire provides a unique opportunity to understand how a short-duration, large-magnitude fire disrupts and changes geological erosion rates owing to an existing dataset of pre-fire erosion rates determined in 2016. Through this project, three undergraduate research students will receive personalized training in Earth science research, analyze real-world data for senior theses, and learn how Earth’s surface changes in response to wildfires.

Geological erosion rates have been determined for thousands of rivers around the world by measuring the concentration of 10-beryllium (10Be) in quartz river sand. Measured 10Be concentrations are only produced in Earth’s near-surface and are thus sensitive to or diluted by short-lived deep-erosion events such as gully erosion, landslides, and debris flows, all of which are common following wildfires. The effect of post-fire erosion on measured 10Be concentrations is largely unknown because it is rare to have existing 10Be data from rivers that are subsequently affected by severe burning. This project benefits from a 10Be dataset collected from seven rivers draining the Santa Monica Mountains in 2016, two years prior to the 2018 Woolsey Fire. Four of these rivers were completely burned by the fire, providing the unique opportunity to (1) quantify how much measured 10Be concentrations in river sand have changed as a result of wildfire-caused erosion in burned catchments and (2) quantify the reproducibility of 10Be concentrations in unburned catchments. This project will have a clear and beneficial impact for the growing number of scientists who use 10Be data in their work because it serves to provide one of the first long-term, systematically-collected 10Be replicate sample sets in a steep, semiarid, fire-prone landscape. Because 10Be-derived erosion rates are used to contextualize modern human-induced sediment runoff, map seismic activity in tectonically-active regions, and assess landscape stability over geologically-meaningful timescales, this work will broadly benefit a wide range of professionals who rely on geomorphologists’ ability to produce accurate and informative interpretations of sediment transport and landscape evolution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Funding from the National Science Foundation was used in this study to assess the reproducibility of the isotope, 10-beryllium (10Be) measured from stream sand being exported out of seven large (10 km2) river basins across the Santa Monica Mountains, California, between the years 2016–2021. 10Be data are used by geologists and Earth scientists to determine landscape erosion rates over geologically short, millennial timescales. In turn, 10Be erosion rates are used to assess how climate, tectonics, topography, and/or rock type influence patterns of landscape evolution. 10Be data are, however, sensitive to deep hillslope erosion, which often follows heavy rainfall and landslides. 10Be data tend not to reproduce well in steep, tectonically active, semi-arid landscapes, like the Santa Monica Mountains because such landscapes are more susceptible to landslides and debris flows. The 2016–2021 period over which this study was run covers numerous wet seasons for southern California, but also spans years before and after the 2018 Woolsey Fire, which was the largest historical wildfire to burn through the Santa Monica Mountains. Deep hillslope erosion often follows wildfires, including the Woolsey Fire, so we were able to use Woolsey Fire and the debris flows that followed to assess how well 10Be data reproduce before and after rare but large-magnitude erosion events. This was the first study to directly assess 10Be reproducibility before and after a wildfire. Testing the reproducibility of 10Be data is important so that interpretations derived from these data, in the Santa Monica Mountains and elsewhere, are geologically accurate.

 

Replicate samples of stream sand for 10Be analysis were collected from each of the seven river basins in the Santa Monica Mountains. Four of the river basins were completely burned by the Woolsey Fire, one was partially burned, and two were not burned. All seven were affected by heavy rainfall associated with southern California’s wet season and atmospheric river events. The 10Be data from the two unburned basins reproduce well over the 2016–2021 time period, but 10Be data measured from the burned basins was more variable. 10Be concentrations from three of the five burned basins returned to pre-fire levels within the three years following the Woolsey Fire. 10Be data from the other two of the five burned basins remained higher than pre-fire levels, at least three years following the fire. We find that 10Be data reproduced relatively well in unburned river basins even though they were also affected by numerous heavy rainfall events, which suggests that long-term 10Be data variability in the burned basins is not likely due to heavy rainfall alone but may be a result of fire-priming the landscape for erosion. All findings from this study support the continued application of 10Be methods in similar tectonically active, steep, semi-arid landscapes.

 

Three undergraduate students from Eastern Michigan University (EMU) were provided with independent research opportunities through this project, and none had participated in research previously. Each student presented their portion of this project at the EMU Undergraduate Research Symposium (the longest-running undergraduate research fair in the United States), and two presented their work in person at national meetings of the Geological Society of America with the third being listed as a presenter. Inclusion of undergraduate researchers from a regional comprehensive university supports NSF’s goals of broadening participation in STEM research.
